She increased the sales and applied for more loans; $600, $800 and $1000. Now she needs $1200 to increase the inventory in the shop.

loans.use: To increase the number of inventories

loans.name: Juliana

texts.es:
Juliana buys leather wallets, pocketbooks and purses and hawks them at fairs in the south of La Paz. She does this work by herself, as her husband works as a laborer. She lives in the neighborhood of Callapa in La Paz. This is the first loan Juliana has requested. She will use the funds to purchase merchandise such as wallets, handbags and the like. She has been in business for four years and IMPRO's analysis of her financial situation recommends her for this loan.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Juliana compra carteras y billeteras de cuero y cuerina y las vende ambulando en las ferias de la zona Sur de la ciudad de La Paz; ella trabaja sola, su esposos es albañil. Vive en la zona de Callapa de la ciudad de La Paz. Es la primera vez que solicita un crédito El monto solicitado será destinado para la compra de mercadería (carteras, billeteras y maletines). Su experiencia de más de cuatro años de trabajo en este rubro le permite acceder a este crédito el cual es aprobado por IMPRO después del respectivo análisis financiero realizado.

loans.use: To buy leather goods for resale.

loans.name: Holotodé

texts.fr:
Mrs. Holotodé E. is a 22 year-old mother of three (3) children whose father is a young motorbike taxi driver. His motor bike often breaks down because it is vey old. Also, this small family lives in poverty and can only afford one meal per day. Although Mrs. Holotodé E. has a business activity of buying corn on credit and reselling it, this is hardly enough to feed the children. Having enough customers and very dynamic, she requests a credit of $600 in order to stock up with a larger amount of corn and beans in the harvest period, thus lowering the cost, and resell it at a higher price when the appropriate time comes. The financing of his project will make it possible for Mrs. E. to avoid buying on credit and will help her escape the misery in which she and her family currently live in.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Agée de 22 ans, Madame E. Holotodé est mère de trois (3) enfants dont le père est d’un jeune conducteur de taxi moto. La moto de ce dernier tombe souvent en panne parce que très vieille. Aussi cette famille vit-elle dans la misère accrue et condamnée à un repas par jour. L’activité de Madame E. Holotodé qui consiste à acheter le maïs à crédit et de le revendre, suffit à peine à nourrir les enfants. Disposant d’assez de clients et très dynamique, elle sollicite un crédit de $600 afin de faire un stockage consistant du maïs et du haricot en cette période de récolte et donc moindre coût et de les revendre très cher au moment venu. Ce projet financé permettra à Madame E. de dégager d’énorme bénéfice servant de fonds de roulement et lui permettant d’éviter d’acheter à crédit et surtout la misère dans laquelle elle et sa famille végètent actuellement.

loans.use: Buying and storing cereals

loans.name: Bahram

texts.en: Bahram lives  in Khachmaz  town and has been runhing his farming business for 3 years. He is 49 years old, married and has three children. . He is requesting a loan of $725 to buy pesticides.

loans.use: Loan to purchase pesticides for his farming business

loans.name: Seema's Group

texts.en:
My name is Seema B. and I'm from a small town in Pakistan. I am married with six children. My group raises livestock and sells their milk in nearby villages. At present, we have four cows, four buffaloes and two goats. We sell approximately 50 kg of milk daily. Our business has grown over the years with the loans we have borrowed from Asasah, a microfinance institution, based in Pakistan. Now we want to buy another cow to increase the milk production. 



We have been friends for years and have acquired various loans together, where we accept repayment responsibility for each other’s loans. My group members are: Aphan B., who owns a few cows and sells their milk; Hamida B., who also sells milk to her neighborhood clients; and Aziz B., whose husband runs a grocery store.  I would like to help all of them so that our community can prosper and women's voices are heard in their houses. We are applying for a loan of $1025 to buy another cow for our dairy business.

loans.use: Expand the group's dairy business by buying another cow

loans.name: Mesepa

texts.en: Mesepa is one of an old member of the Levili center. She is 29, and presently residing at Levili village. Her business is a flea market, selling vegetables and general goods just in front of her house. Her main customers are passing traffic and village people. She used to earn about $80-120 USD a week, and that is the only place she gets financial support for her family.

loans.use: To restock her flea market stall

loans.name: Luzmila

texts.en:
Luzmila has been a part of the community bank “Señor D. Luren” for 10 years. She is 62 years old, widowed and has eight children, six of whom are still living with her. In the community bank Luzmila has learned to be responsible, punctual, how to invest her money, how to save, as well as to be more understanding.

Luzmila sells a typical ice cream from the region called “Muyuchi” which is maD. from fresh mild, coconut, cinnamon, and sugar. She needs a loan of 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which will be invested in buying sugar, milk, coconut, and salt.

Each member of the community bank has an interest earning savings account. Luzmila plans to use hers to pay for the things that her children need. Her dream is that her children will be professionals.

loans.use: Luzmila needs a loan of 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which will be invested in buying sugar, milk, coconut, and salt.

loans.name: Kirangira East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sarah K.. She is currently in the business of selling used clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes to sell. Sarah is 47 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 8 children ranging from age 9 to 25 and her children go to school. Each week, Sarah makes approximately UGX 18000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to boost business and educate her children. Sarah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to add to her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Sarah is joined in her small group by Joy K., Rashida K., Faith M., and Suzan N.. Joy K. has a business rearing chickens and cows and wants to purchase more chicks and feed. Rashida K. is currently operating a cow rearing business and wants a loan to expand the business. Faith M. operates a business of sugarcane growing and wants to boost business and increase output. Suzan N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add stock.

loans.use: To add to clothing business

loans.name: Elida Angelica

texts.es:
Elida Angélica R. Cárdenas belongs to the “Santa Rosa de Lima” comunal bank. She lives in Juanjui district, Mariscal Cáceres province, San Martín department. She has a phone booth business with two phone booths, which is located at Number 880 Jr. Triunfo Street. People who live in the community come everyday to make their local, long-distance, and international phone calls, to both land lines and cellular phones.

Thanks to her hard work and a loan she received, she was able to open this business. She currently has many customers, thanks to the good way she treats people and her charismatic character.

With a loan of S/. 1,700.00, which will be returned in 6 months, she will buy more telephone cabins and sell more sweets.

Elida is 25 years old and lives with her husband and young child. She works tirelessly to have good results from her business and to feel useful in life, with many opportunities in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Elida Angélica R. Cárdenas pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima”, vive en la región San Martín, provincia Mariscal Cáceres y distrito de Juanjui, tiene un Locutorio con dos cabinas telefónicas que está ubicado en Jr. Triunfo N º 880 a la que diariamente acuden los moradores de la comunidad a realizar sus llamadas locales, naciones o internaciones , hacia teléfonos fijos y celulares. Gracias a sus esfuerzos y al préstamo recibido logró tener ese servicio, actualmente tiene varios clientes gracias al buen trato y a su manera carismática. Con el reciente crédito recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,700.00, el cual será devuelto en 6 meses, comprará más cabinas telefónicas e implementar mejor su negocio de golosinas. La señora Elida tiene 25 años, vive con su esposo y su pequeño hijo, trabaja incansablemente para poder ver los resultados y sentirse útil en la vida con muchas perspectivas en el futuro.

loans.use: To buy more telephone cabins

loans.name: Priskila's Peace Group

texts.en:
Priskila is 31 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 11, 8 and 4 years old. Priskila is a milk seller, and she started in 2001. Every day, she works from 6 am to 8 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $65 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more milk for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in milk sales.

loans.use: To buy more milk for her business.

loans.name: Lam Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Lam Thi D. is 25 years old, and her husband is 27 years old. They have a son who is 2 years old. Although at such a young age, the couple works very hard to build their future. Mrs. D.'s husband is a mason, and Mrs. D. is a farmer. On average, their family income is around 130 USD a month. In 2007, Mrs. D. became a member of TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) to borrow some money to breed animals . Her husband also helps her with the biweekly repayment. In an auction recently, Mrs. D. and her husband just won a contract to breed fish in their village's fish pond. This loan term, she wants to borrow 700 USD to buy fish and fishfood.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Lâm Thị Diệu năm nay 25 tuổi còn chồng chị 27 tuổi. Hai anh chị có một con trai 2 tuổi. Tuy còn trẻ nhưng hai vợ chồng chị Diệu rất chịu khó làm kinh tế. Anh đi làm thợ nề, chị ở nhà làm ruộng và chăn nuôi. Thu nhập hàng tháng của gia đình khoảng 130USD. Năm 2007 chị Diệu tham gia vay vốn của Quỹ Tình thương về chăn nuôi. Sau một năm tham gia, chị cảm thấy ngày càng yêu thích với cách vay vốn lớn hoàn trả nhỏ của Quỹ. Chồng chị lại làm có tiền công hàng ngày, có thể hỗ trợ vợ nên việc hoàn trả rất thuận tiện. Vừa qua gia đình chị Diệu đã trúng thầu khu ao thả cá của thôn. Vòng vốn này chị Diệu xin vay 700USD để mua cá về thả cùng thức ăn cho chăn nuôi.

loans.use: Buy fishes and food for them

loans.name: Ni Made Kerti

texts.id:
Ni Made Kerti has been married to I Made Media for 35 years. Her husband is a carpenter / wood statue makers for local temples. However he is making less money than he used to, worsening their family's financial condition. This situation decided to start a pig farm with financial support from DINARI foundation. Made Kerti used her first loan from DINARI to purchase 2 piglets that were sold 6 months later when they matured for $70 profit. Currently Ni Made Kerti is seeking second loan from DINARI to purchase more piglets so she can farm more pigs and increase the profit making potential of her farm. Hopefully the income from the farm can improve her family's financial condition.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Ni Made Kerti telah hidup bersama dengan suaminya I Made Madia selama 35 tahun. Penghasilan suaminya sebagai seorang pemahat kayu untuk tempat persembahyangan semakin hari semakin merosot membuat perekonomian keluarga Ni Made Kerti pas-pasan. Oleh karena itu Made Kerti memutuskan untuk memelihara babi yang didukung oleh program DINARI dengan cara peminjaman modal. Dengan pinjaman pertama yang diperoleh Made Kerti untuk pembelian 2 ekor bibit babi penggemukan yang kemudian dijual setelah 6 bulan Made Kerti meraup keuntungan sebesar Rp.600.000,- Dari situ Made Kerti kembali melakukan pinjaman periode kedua ke DINARI untuk menambah bibit babi peliharaannya sehingga keuntungan yang diperoleh pun akan bertambah. Dan hal ini tentunya akan meningkatkan penghasilan keluarganya.

loans.use: Purchase Piglets and Increase Number of Farmed Pigs

loans.name: Juan German

texts.es:
Juan began his business in order to support his children and give them an education as he wishes a better quality of life for them. He began his grocery store in 2006 with little merchandise, and little by little he bought more items that people requested, until he was able to fully establish his store.

He needs a loan for US$250, which will be repaid in 3 months, to stock merchandise and be able to sell more, thereby improving his income. With your help Juan will be able to grow his business.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Juan inicio el negocio para poder mantener a sus hijos y darles educacion, ya que desea una mejor calidad de vida para ellos. Comenzo su tienda de abarrotes en el año 2006 con poca mercancia y poco a poco fue comprando mercancia que la gente le solictaba, hasta que logro tener su tienda mas establecida.

El necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para surtir mercancia y poder vender mas y mejorar sus ingresos. Con tu apoyo Juan hara crecer su negocio.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to sell in his store

loans.name: Felipa Del Socorro

texts.es:
L. is 36 years old, single and has no children. She lives in a small home built on her own efforts with plank walls and earthen floors. She is requesting a loan to tile her home and thus improve her living conditions. She works for Asunción Hospital and the San Ramón Clinic. In her home, she uses solar energy and when it's cloudy she doesn't turn on her lights, but she still is able to use electric appliances like her TV and speakers. She repaid her first loan before the allotted time and has an excellent credit history. She wants to improve her home because the rainy season has made it very muddy. Eventually, she hopes to put up concrete walls to add more security. Currently she is not concerned about a robbery because her mother lives next door, who takes care of it while she is at work.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva volunteer

La joven L., soltera con 36 años de edad, sin hijos, habita en una casita pequeña construida por esfuerzo propio es de paredes de tabla, pizo de tierra, su crédito lo está solicitando para embaldozar y asi tener mejores condiciones, trabaja para el hospital Asunción y la clínica San Ramón, en su vivienda utiliza energía solar y cuando está nublado no encienden las lámparas, pero sí sus aparatos eléctricos como T.V. y equipo de sonido. Esta señora su primer crédito lo canceló antes de la fecha establecida, presentando un excelente récord créditicio, moral de pago y responsabilidad ante los compromisos asumidos, desea mejorar su vivienda porque en la época lluviosa se le hace mucho lodo, posteriormente desea levantar las paredes de concreto, para dar mayor seguridad a su vivienda, en estos momentos no se le han presentado problemas de robo porque junto a su casita está la casa de su mamá, quien le cuida cuando ella está en su trabajo.

loans.use: Tile the floor of her home / Embaldozar piso de su vivienda

loans.name: Abigail

texts.es: Sus bajos recursos económicos y problemas personales nunca derrotaron Abigail,  joven perseverante de 28 años, desde adolescente buscó innumerables formas de generar sus propios ingresos económicos, así poco a poco independizarse  y apoyar a sus padres en la educación de sus hermanos menores.Luego de tentar suerte con varios negocios, decidió dedicarse íntegramente a la comercialización de prendas usadas, esta actividad le está permitiendo acabar con sus obstáculos económicos, y al mismo tiempo ayudar a sus padres en la educación  y alimentación de sus  hermanos menores.En estos momentos tiene grandes anhelos que la motivan a seguir adelante, pero requiere del préstamo que solicita para  cumplirlos, vender más y aumentar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Scarce economic resources and personal problems have never gotten the better of Abigail, a persevering 28-year-old woman. Ever since she was a teenager, she has found innumerable ways to generate her own income, and bit by bit has been able to become independent. She even helps her parents pay for her younger siblings' education. After trying her luck with several different businesses, Abigail decided to fully dedicate herself to selling used clothing, and this activity has helped her overcome economic obstacles and help her parents educate and feed her younger brothers and sisters. Today, Abigail has great dreams that compel her to continue to strive, but she needs the loan she is requesting to fulfill these dreams by selling more and increasing her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase used clothing to sell

loans.name: Sarakhoun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarakhoun Thaugn, 49, and her husband, Mr. Hoeun Chea, 51, live along national road number one about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1979 and have seven children; five sons and two daughters. Two of their children have full time employment. Two children study in the local school.

Mrs. Thaugn has been a grocery seller for one year. She buys grocery items from the Korky market to resell to villagers at her home. Her husband has been a fisherman for ten years. Sarakhoun is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a stock of more grocery items to resell.

loans.use: Sarakhoun would like to purchase grocery item for her shop.

loans.name: Shemu John's Kinyerezi Group

texts.en:
Shemu J., 31, is married with two children, ages three and two, and also cares for two dependents – his sister-in-law and niece. He has a shop where he sells beauty supplies in an area called Banana. He started this business in 2007 and works daily from 8 a.m. until 8 p.m., earning a monthly profit of around $81.

This will be Shemu’s third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans, which he promptly repaid, to increase the stock of his shop, and now hopes for a third loan to buy more stock, such as lotions and jewelry.

Shemu will share this loan with his loan group, Kinyerezi, whose members hold each other accountable in repaying their loans. In the picture, Shemu is standing second from the right and is wearing a black shirt. Also pictured are J. N. (fruit and vegetable stand owner), Vitus S. (butchery owner) and Christian M. (bar owner).

loans.use: To increase the stock of his beauty supplies shop.

loans.name: Adela

texts.es: Adela es madre soltera, vive junto con sus hijos y las familias de ellos, quienes le hacen compañía y apoyan en todo. Ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes y productos de primera necesidad desde hace 3 años, lo que le gusta de su trabajo es conocer mucha gente y dar un trato amable al momento de vender. Le es rentable porque gracias a este negocio y a su carisma al atender, cuenta con una gran clientela. Lo difícil para ella es no contar con un local adecuado para la venta de sus productos. Este es su segundo préstamo con MFP. Su propósito para invertir este dinero es ampliar y construir un kiosco para su negocio, comprar más productos y surtirlo adecuadamente.
texts.en:
Adela is a single mother who lives with her children and their families, who keep her company and support her in everything. She has sold groceries and essential goods for 3 years and what she likes about her job is meeting a lot of people and being friendly while she is selling to them. This business is profitable thanks to her charm in dealing with the clients. The difficult thing for her is not having a suitable place to sell her products. This is her second loan with MFP. The purpose of this loan is to expand and build a kiosk for her business, to buy more products and display them properly.

Translated from Spanish by Jeanette Chase, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a kiosk to sell her products.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
Pedro se dedica a la cría de ganado vacuno, cuya producción de leche lo comercializa a PIL Andina (Planta Industrializadota de Leche). Además trabaja como albañil en la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Vive. en la comunidad Chojasivi de la Provincia Loa Andes del departamento de La Paz ubicado  a cuatro horas de la ciudad de La Paz.

Vive junto a su esposa y sus cuatro hijos. 
 
El crédito lo destinara en la compra de una vaca lechera y así incrementar  la producción de leche, por lo tanto sus ingresos.
 
Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo
texts.en:
Pedro is dedicated to raise cattle. His milk production is sold to PIL Andina (Milk Industrialization Plant). He also works as a bricklayer in the city of El Alto. He lives in the Chojasivi community of the Loa Andes province of the La Paz department located 4 hours from the capital city of La Paz. He lives with his wife and four children.

The loan will be used to buy a milk cow and increase the milk production and his earnings as well. It is his first loan with Impro and the evaluation done qualifies him to receive the loan.


Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Ugiloy

texts.en:
B. Ugiloy is 39 years old, married and the loving mother of four children. She is a vendor and for the last thirteen years has been selling cottonseed oil at the local market. In the traditional Tajik cuisine the majority of meals are fried or cooked using cottonseed oil. Our national dish “Oshi palov” especially uses a great deal of cottonseed oil to make it delicious. So the goods that Uguloy sells are in great demand by the population. Today she is planning to increase her business and for this reason she has requested a loan of 3000 Somoni for the term of twelve months. The loan will be used to purchase more cottonseed oil in order to increase her inventory. Ugiloy is counting on your help and thanks you for your support. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was a key post along the Silk Road and is where the rule of Alexander the Great ended. It is famous for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more cottonseed oil in order to increase her inventory

loans.name: Maleyka

texts.en:
Maleyka Q. is a 54-year-old woman who runs a store, where she sells food products such as juices, tea, candies, and cookies. She is married with 3 children.

With the first loan she received from Aqroinvest, Maleyka was able to increase her stock. Now, Maleyka would like to apply for a second loan to increase the variety of food products in her store. For this purpose, she applied for a 1200 USD loan. Maelyka successfully repaid her first loan to Agroinvest.

loans.use: Purchase food products

loans.name: Amin

texts.en:
Amin F. is 49 years old. He is married with two children. Amin has a great passion for dairy farming and has been in this business for 20 years together with his wife and elder son (pictured). He would like to expand his business by adding another cow to the ones he has. This is because recently he acquired orders from outside town to supply milk. Amin is requesting a loan of $500 in order to buy another cow and feed. With the additional income, Amin will be better able to cater to his family's financial obligations, especially the education of his children.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; for the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, like Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing a cow and feed

loans.name: Fortaleza Group

texts.es:
Este grupo del Barrio Chaipe surgió por contacto de una de las integrantes con la fundación. Todas las señoras realizan actividades productivas como ser : venta de comidas, almacen, peluqueria, despensa, confeccion de cortinados, venta de frutas y verduras , venta de ropas v, venta de cosmeticos . El monto que recibe cada señora varía de 300.000 a 1.200.000, todas las señoras destinan el crédito para las actividades que ya estan realizando actualmente. 

1.	Apolonia Quiñonez Paiva - Venta de Ropas
2.	María Lourdes F. - Peluquería y Cantina
3.	Mariela Peña - Venta de comestibles 
4.	Gladys P. -Almacen 
5.	Nancy González -Despensa
6.	Mercedes Báez -Kiosko
7.	Lidia V. de León -Venta de comestibles
8.	María Perla Y. -Modista
9.	Antonia Báez Ibarra -Cotillón
10.	María Angelica A. -Almacen
11.	Lisandra Morínigo - Venta de Cubiertos
12.	Griselda Fernández -Venta de Comestibles 
13.	Idalia Monzón -Venta de frutas y verduras
14.	Gertrudis León González - Venta de Ropas
15.	Dalmin Nuñez - Venta de Cosmeticos
16.	Cristel Y. López - Cortinados
17.	María Fátima A. - Venta de Ropas
texts.en:
The Chaipe del Barrio group came into being through one of the partners of the foundation. All the women work productively which include: food sales, store owners, hairdressers, pantries, curtain making, fruit and vegetable sales, clothing sales, and cosmetic sales. The amount each woman receives varies from 300,000 to 1,200,000, all the women will apply their loans to the work they are already undertaking. 1. Apolonia Quiñonez Paiva – Clothing sales 2. María Lourdes F. – Hairdresser and bartender 3. Mariela Peña – Food sales 4. Gladys P. – Grocery store 5. Nancy González – Pantry 6. Mercedes Báez – Kiosk 7. Lidia V. de León – Food sales 8. María Perla Y. – Dressmaker 9. Antonia Báez Ibarra – Dance hall 10. María Angelica A. – Grocery store 11. Lisandra Morínigo – Cutlery sales 12. Griselda Fernández – Food sales 13. Idalia Monzón – Fruit and vegetable sales 14. Gertrudis León González – Clothing sales 15. Dalmin Nuñez – Cosmetic sales 16. Cristel Y. López – Curtain making 17. María Fátima A. – Clothing sales

Translated from Spanish by Jennie Campos, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing, food items for kiosks and pantries, such as flour, oil, noodles, cigarettes, tea, beverages, meat, cutlery, fabrics, cosmetics and hairdressing

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita S. is 62 years old and still active in her business. She and her husband have three children: Bob is now 44 years old, Benivida is 42 years old and the youngest Bienvinido is 41 years old. All of their children are married. The eldest supports his family through farming, while Benivida and Bienvinido both work abroad. Estelita and Artemio (her husband) are already weak but still strive to support their daily life. 

Estelita runs a general store where she generates an average net income of PHP300 a day. She wants to purchase additional merchandise for her store, such as cans of cooking oil, sacks of sugar and salt, soap and other goods, in order to meet the demand of her customers. She is requesting a PHP15,000 loan for financial assistance, which will contribute a lot to her business and to the education of her grandchildren.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items.

loans.name: Cathrine

texts.en: Cathrine A. is a divorced mother of 3 children who has received an education through Senior High School.  Cathrine has worked as a trader in Elmina selling a variety of food items such as groundnuts and beans since 1999.  She uses her income to pay for school fees and bills. Cathrine would like a loan to purchase maize, groundnuts, and beans in a larger quantity which she will then prepare and sell.  With the additional profits from her expanded business, Cathrine plans to save and further her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase a larger quantity of maize, groundnuts, and beans to help grow her business.

loans.name: Mahmadjon

texts.en:
I. Mahmadjon is 25 years old and is married. He is an expert in computer services and cell phone repairing. He provides computer services such as: printing, scanning, lamination and etc. He is in this business for 2 years already. Mahmadjon tries to use modern up-to-date technologies in his work so that satisfying the demands and requirements of the customers. Now he is planning to purchase additional tools and spare parts requiring for the repair of cell phones. With this purpose Mahmadjon requests $ 3000 US Dollars. This is the first loan of Mahmadjon and he thanks all for support and promises not to let down and to pay the loan in time. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of tools and spare parts requiring for the repair of cell phones.

loans.name: Fayaza Group

texts.en:
Fayaza is the leader of this group of four. The members want to take a group loan of 56000 Afghani to help improve their businesses.

Fayaza wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. Bibi Fatama wants to take a loan for her husband's general store. Hanesa wants to take a loan for her husband's carpentry shop. Anesa wants to take a loan for her embroidery business.

They would all like to expand their businesses with this loan. They want to support their families and make a better future for them.

loans.use: To expand her tailoring business

loans.name: Sharifa

texts.ru: Шарифа Мирзоева проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 47 лет. Женат, имеет 10 детей. Шарифа более 6 лет занимается животноводством. Ее сыновья находятся в России, на заработках, муж занимается услугой такси. Шарифа покупает скот, откармливает и продает. Клиентка просит кредит, для покупки крупно рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Sharifa M. lives in the city of Kulob. She is 47 years old, married and has 10 children. Sharifa has been involved in animal husbandry for over 6 years. Her sons work in Russia, and her husband works as a taxi driver. Sharifa buys livestock, feeds it and resells it. Our client is requesting this loan in order to buy cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius Njeru I. is a 34-year-old father of two school-going children aged 9 and 8 years. He is asking for a first loan of Ksh. 20,000 to expand his shoe vending and repair business in the Mukuru Slum in Nairobi, Kenya. Having faced challenges of insufficient capital and lack of education, Julius is determined to expand his small business. He sells shoes and shoe laces and repairs shoes. With this loan, Julius plans to buy additional stock for his business and expand it.

In the future, Julius hopes to own a shoe manufacturing company, employ people, buy and develop rental houses, manage his own businesses and give his children education to the highest level and the best care one can give. Julius describes himself as hardworking, diligent and social.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Buy additional stock

loans.name: Eda Elena

texts.es:
Eda es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Huanca.
Eda es casada, tiene 43 años y 8 hijos, Eda viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde compra quesos, animales menores, productos que comercializa de casa en casa en la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Eda necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de queso y gallinas.
Eda sueña con brindar una buena educación a sus hijos y tener una casa propia.
texts.en:
Eda is a partner of the Community Bank of Señor de Huanca. Eda is married, 43 years old, and has 8 children. Eda travels to different festivals in the region where she buys cheeses andsmall animals, products she sells house to house in the city of Ayacucho. She needs a loan of $225 that will be invested in the purchase of cheese and chickens. She dreams of giving a good education to her children and having her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Amy Schapiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of cheese and chickens

loans.name: Bob's Group

texts.en: Bob K. is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is 39, married and has 2 children; one is in school. He works from Mukono central market, where he is one of the executives managing the market, and he also has a stall where he sells local chickens. Bob does not have a poultry farm but he buys chickens from farmers in Busoga, Kayunga, and from western Uganda, where they are a bit cheaper, so that by reselling he can make a profit. He needs a loan to buy large numbers of chickens, since this saves on transport costs and the price is lower when you buy large numbers. With the profits, Bob will be able to pay for his child’s school fees and take care of his family.

loans.use: Buying more local chickens for resale so as to make more profits.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 36, married and has one daughter who is out of school. She works very hard to support her husband and help provide for the family. She lives with her daughter and husband in a rented apartment in Oda in the Eastern region of Ghana. Mary is a food vendor. She cooks and sells rice and stew on the street in her community in the mornings. She buys her raw materials from Kumasi. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Mariana Califonha

texts.pt:
Mariana nasceu na província de Tete, no norte de Moçambique, (onde se localiza a hidroelétrica de cahora-bassa, uma das maiores de áfrica). Tem 53 anos de idade, casado e mãe de 7 filhos com idades compreendidas entre 7 e 22 anos que freqüentam escolas publicas de boane. Vive com mais um sobrinho que esta sob sua responsabilidade. Estudou ate 3 classe do tempo colonial e parou quando contraiu grávida. Mais tarde ingressou nas fileiras das forcas armadas de libertação Nacional, para a independência do pais do jugo colonial.

Vive na casa própria com sua família (marido, filhos e sobrinho). Para alem da família cuida da sua mãe no mesmo espaço físico da casa.

Saiu de Tete no ano de 1981 a boane, sozinha, ao encontro do seu marido que encontrava se em missão de serviço militar. Mariana também  foi militar, combatente da luta de libertação nacional juntamente com seu marido e ambos são pensionistas do ministério da defesa nacional. Conheceram se na tropa antes do fim da guerra.
Cada um recebe 5.740,00MT e totalizam 11.480,00MT, mensalmente, que aplicam no sustento da família e construção da casa de alvenaria.

Teve credito com outras instituições similares e diz que ouviu falar da Hluvuku-Adsema através dos vizinhos e clientes da instituição que acharam a  modalidade de pagamento democrático (o cliente define o valor de pagamento mensal segundo as suas capacidades e pode fechar antes do tempo sem penelização ).

Este vai ser o segundo empréstimo da Mariana na instituição no valor de 12.000,00MT para compra de material de construção (cimento, areia e outros). O primeiro credito de 10.000,00MT também foi para a mesma actividade. 

Propõe se a pagar o empréstimo sem problemas para poder aceder a mais créditos com intuito de concluir a obra e fortalecer o negocio.
texts.en:
Mariana was born in the Tete province, in northern Mozambique (where the Cahora-Bassa hydroelectric dam is located, one of the largest in Africa.) She is 53 years old, and is married with 7 children between ages 7 and 22. Her children attend public schools in Boane. She also supports one of her nephews who lives with her. She attended school until the third grade during the colonial era, but stopped when she became pregnant. Later she enlisted in the armed forces of the national liberation, for independence from the colonial yoke. She lives in her own home with her family (husband, children, and nephew). She also cares for her mother in her home. She left Tete in 1981 for Boane, alone, to meet up with her husband who was in the military. Mariana was also in the military, and fought for independence along with her husband. Both she and her husband receive a pension from the Ministry of National Defense. They met in the military before the end of the war. Each of them receives 5.740.00MT monthly, totaling 11.480.00MT, which they use to support their family and for construction of a cement block home. Mariana had loans with other similar institutions and said that she heard about Hluvuku-Adsema through two neighbors who were clients of Hluvuku-Adsema and found the payment method to be democratic (the client defines the monthly payment in accordance with his/her ability to pay and can pay off the loan early without any penalties). This will be Mariana's second loan, in the amount of 12.000,00MT for the purchase of construction materials (cement, sand, etc.). Her first loan was for 10.000,00MT for the same purposes. She plans to pay back the loan without any problems in order to have access to additional loans to finish her home and strengthen her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, sand, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys sells dry fish and fresh tomatoes. Dry fish is very suitable for the preparation of fish meals, soup and sauces. Gladys is 53 years old and married with five children who are currently in school. She obtains her supply from big-time fishmongers. She wants to use this loan to buy dry fish and vegetables in bulk to meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to pay her children’s educational fees.

loans.use: To purchase assorted fish

loans.name: High Society Group

texts.en: Justice is forty years old. He is divorced and has two children. Both of his children are in school. He lives with his children in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Justice is a trader. He trades in palm oil. He is the leader of a trust bank group called High Society. Most of the group members are either into trading or farming activities. The group requests a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses. Justice, the group leader is seated in the photograph. It is their desire to give their children the best education they can afford.

loans.use: To buy supplies of palm oil for resale

loans.name: Shadia

texts.en:
Shadia is the mother of four children. Her husband works as a peddler so he doesn't have a stable income. Things got worse for him after Israel established the separation wall in addition to crossing checkpoints which spread all over the West Bank. That makes it even harder for him to travel between cities.

Shadia decided to help her husband by doing embroidery and selling it to shops, neighbors, and on request. She received several loans from FATEN and repaid them in full and on time. Now she requests 600 Jordanian Dinar (1 JOD=0.71 USD) to buy cloth, thread and beads.

Shadia appears in the photo with one of her products.

loans.use: To purchase cloth, thread and beads

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase fertilizer and soil amendments

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma A. is from the village of Puntod Lopez Jaena Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old. Vilma is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Vilma owns and operates an agricultural business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising fish for sale. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Vilma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to expand her business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Vilma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to provide for the basic needs of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa C., 57, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Jovencio C., a taxi driver, she makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been direct selling branded clothes and managing her own variety store for five years.

Elsa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow nine times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy stocks for her store. Her two businesses let her earn a profit of PHP 5,500 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying assorted snacks and beverages for her store and additional products for her direct selling business.

She dreams that her business will grow so that her youngest child can finish college and help all her children improve their lives. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy products for her store and direct selling business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fish

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional tomatoes, onions and other vegetables

loans.name: Yoribek

texts.en:
Born in 1949, Yoribek is married and the father of three adult children. Although he is primarily a farmer, he also raises animals, a sideline that he feels passionate about. Selling animals he has raised is his special source of income. However, Yoribek raises his animals in the traditional fashion, which does not provide much in the way of financial returns. Interested in modernizing his operation to earn more from it, Yoribek would like to build a pen for his animals and also add other cattle to his flocks. Accomplishing this will allow him to increase his income and better provide for his family.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To build a pen and purchase cattle

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria H. is currently in the business of selling clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a supermarket. Victoria is 33 years old and is married to a logistics officer. She has four children and her children go to school. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Kugumikiriza Development Group, Jinja

texts.en:
With ten grownup school-going children and one dependent to cater for, 47-year-old cheerful bread-winner, Z. Simon, has no choice but to work excessively hard selling his fruits and vegetables in Jinja central market. This has been his main source of livelihood for the last twenty-two years.

With the little income from his business, Simon has managed to provide for his wife, kids and relatives. In good weather months, he says he makes profits totaling 100,000 shillings or even more. His main source of lamentation over the years has been the bad weather spells which, in effect, mean he has to make do with fewer supplies from farmers.

What has made Simon’s business grow is the fact that he has struck a chord with most of his clients and suppliers on the basis of his good business line of conduct. His future plans are to be able to easily transport his fruits and vegetables to his clients far away from his operating place.

With this loan, Simon says he is going to boost his business by paying for more deliveries of fruit and vegetable supplies from his farming business partners.

loans.use: To pay for more deliveries of fresh fruit and vegetable supplies

loans.name: María Judith

texts.es:
María Judith  D. es socia del banco comunal  San Pedro ubicado en la comunidad que lleva el mismo nombre en  la parroquia Victoria de  Portete en la parte suroccidental del cantón Cuenca. Limita al norte con la parroquia Tarqui, al este la parroquia Cumbe, al sur la periferia del cantón Girón y al oeste  la parroquia San Gerardo del  cantón Girón y la parroquia Baños. Es un encantador lugar donde se levanta  un hermoso monumento en honor a los héroes de la Batalla de Tarqui, en este lugar se libró la batalla entre los ejércitos ecuatoriano y peruano, nuestro ejército estuvo comandado por el Gral. Antonio José de Sucre.

María tiene 58 años, casada y con ocho hijos de ellos cuatro son casados y los otros cuatro son  solteros y viven con ella,  su esposo y dos nietos de los cuales se hizo cargo, su cónyuge  trabaja como estibador y sus  hijos de manera independiente pero sólo para solventar sus gastos personales. Gracias al esfuerzo  y sacrificio de los dos ahora cuentan  con su casa propia

 Nuestra socia se dedica a agricultura actividad que realiza varios años, también cría cuyes, pollos, tiene ganado vacuno y la  leche  que obtiene de sus vacas es para su hogar así como algunos animales. Formó parte de éste grupo de mujeres emprendedoras y luchadoras invitada por su hermana hace tres años, los préstamos obtenidos ha invertido en su hogar y con el nuevo  credito comprará cuyes, pollos y alimento para incrementar su criadero.

Su sueño es ver  a sus hijos superarse en todos los aspectos.
texts.en:
María Judith D. is a member at the communal bank San Pedro, located in the community of San Pedro, Victoria de Portete parish, in the southeastern part of the Cuenca canton. It is a charming place where a heroes monument has been erected. María is 58 years old, is married, and has eight children, four of whom are married. The other four live with her, her husband, and two grandchildren of whom she takes care. María's husband is a longshoreman and her children work to cover their personal expenses. Thanks to María's and her husband's sacrifice, they now own their own home. María has worked in agriculture for several years. She also raises chickens, guinea pigs, and cows. Some of the animals and the milk her cows produce are for María's use at home. María became a member of this group of hardworking, fighting, and entrepreneurial women three years ago thanks to an invitation from her sister. The loans she has obtained she has used to better her home. With this new loan, she will buy guinea pigs, chickens, and animal feed. María's dream is to see her children succeed in all aspects of life.

Translated from Spanish by Violeta Rubiani, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying chickens, guinea pigs, and feed

loans.name: Maria Angelica De

texts.es: Maria Angelica tiene 45 años de edad, está casada y tiene tres hijos que estudian. La familia de Maria Angelica vive en un domicilio que es prestado. Maria Angelica y su esposo son dueños de una pensión familiar que es de su propiedad, ambos cuentan con 5 años de experiencia en este rubro de las comidas. La competencia en el mercado donde tienen su pensión es alta por estar ubicada en lugar estratégico pero así también es elevada la demanda por los almuerzos ya que la afluencia de gente por estos sectores es bastante elevada. Maria Angelica destinó el préstamo para comprar menajes o materiales de cocina que requiere para ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes. Maria Angelica tiene buen historial crediticio tanto en nuestra institución como en el sistema financiero.
texts.en:
Maria Angelica is 45 years old, is married, and has two children in school. Maria Angelica's family lives in a borrowed space. Maria Angelica and her husband own a family guest house. They both have 5 years' experience in the field of food services. The competition in the market where they have their guest house is high because of its strategic location, but so is the demand for meals, since the people in the area are quite affluent. Maria Angelica intends to use the loan to buy kitchenwares and supplies she needs to give her cutomers better service. Maria Angelica has good credit history, both with our institution and in the financial system in general.

Translated from Spanish by Nadine Riopel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of kitchenwares

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Mrs. Leng S., 27, lives in Phnom Penh city, in Cambodia. She has had a job as a garment laborer in industry for years. She earns a salary of over $90 a month, helping to ensure her family has a stable income. She currently cares for a lovely young child, who is not going to school. She is married to Sarun, 28, who works with her in the same factory.

The rice comes to maturity this season; Leng S. wants to take this good occasion to earn more revenue by investing as a rice trader. Because she doesn’t have capital, Leng S. decided to request a $400 loan in order to buy rice in bulk to resell. She is hopeful that the loan will update her family’s financial situation.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk to resell

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie S. is from the village of  Consolacion, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 39 years old. Rosemarie is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosemarie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rosemarie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rosemarie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Consolacion, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Basaminda

texts.en: Basaminda D. is from the village of Potungan, Dapitan City. She is 58 years old, married and has four adult children. To make a living, Zenaida buys and sells seasonal fruits. The main source of income for the business comes from selling lanzones, a native fruit, in the local community. Basaminda has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2007, Basaminda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Basaminda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Basaminda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fruits to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Basaminda from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for fruit vending

loans.name: Kok

texts.en:
Kok K., 53, lives in the Takeo province with her husband and five children. She makes about $3 daily selling groceries, while her husband makes $1.50 as a construction worker. Beside these businesses, this couple also grows rice to support their family. 

She is asking for a loan in the amount of $1,200 to purchase more groceries to expand her current shop and to buy a water pump to irrigate her farmland. She is also hoping to purchase a pig to raise and sell with the money from the loan. She sees this loan as a great opportunity to expand her business and is confident that she will see her income increase as a result.

loans.use: Expand grocery products and purchase a water pump

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma D. is from the village of Alinam, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Norma is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Norma owns & operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling vegetables in the local community. Norma has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Norma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Norma is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Norma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Mediatrice

texts.en:
Mediatrice is 38 years old and is married with three children: the first one is 17, the next is 15 and the last is 13 years old.

Mediatrice owns a business selling maize flour. She has been a businesswoman for a long time, obviously, because she has an experience of ten years in her business. However, even though she is seasoned in her business, she is not able to satisfy her customers. 

Mediatrice is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to be used in her business. With this loan, she will be able to attract more customers which will help her to earn more profits through selling larger quantities.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Mykola

texts.en:
Mykola is married with a grown son. He is a businessman from Ivano-Frankivsk selling retail items, i.e. men’s underwear, household textiles, sheets, etc. Mykola runs his trade in the Central Market of his home town. He offers a nice selection of merchandise at reasonable price. Mykola has been running the business for 3 years. Presently, his monthly profit amounts to 5,000 Grivnyas. 

Mykola is seeking a 7,500 Grivnya loan to purchase 200 socks, 40 towels, 40 blankets and assorted men’s underwear for further retail sale. His son is actively helping run the business. Retail vending is the main source of income for the family. Mykola is happy to be self-employed. He says he remembers back when he used to serve in the military and could hardly make ends meet. Mykola is hoping to keep re-investing in his business and thus open his own little clothing store one day.

loans.use: to purchase 200 pairs of socks, 40 towels, 40 blankets, and assorted underwear

loans.name: Cesar Augusto

texts.es:
Cesar de 38 años, es vendedor de frutas informal, vive en una zona urbana llamada “Suburbio” caracterizada porque la mayoría de habitantes son comerciantes informales. 

Inicio hace 9 años ya que su mama tenia un puesto de frutas en el mercado la “Gran Colombia” cuando el era pequeño y le ayudaba para solventar los gastos de su familia. Después de haber muerto su mama quiso seguir con el mismo negocio de ella, y ubico un pequeño puesto de frutas. Trabaja desde las 05h00am hasta las 18h30pm vendiendo jugos de frutas. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar frutas de toda clase para hacer jugos de frutas. En el futuro quiere tener un bar de frutas y comprar un carro para movilizar mejor su negocio.
texts.en:
Cesar, 38 years old, has a small business selling fruits and lives in an urban area called "Suburbio." This area is called "Suburbio" because most of the inhabitants are small business owners. He started this business nine years ago because when he was a boy he used to help his mother take care of the household bills with her fruit stand in the "Gran Colombia" market. After his mother's death, he wanted to continue on with her business so he set up his small fruit stand. He works from five a.m. to six p.m. selling fruit juices. With the loan he wants to buy a variety of fruits to make juice and in the future he would like to have a fruit bar and buy a car to be able to transport his buisiness more easily.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fuits

loans.name: Pastora

texts.es: Pastora V. C. de 75 años de edad, reside en Cojutepeque, ubicado en el departamento de Cuscatlán, lugar en el cual vive junto a sus nietas menores de edad. Ella es una señora muy esforzada y trabajadora, posee una tienda de productos perecederos y de productos de primera necesidad, la cual es un gran apoyo tanto para ella como para sus nietas quienes dependen de este negocio. Pastora trabaja muy duro para brindarles todo lo necesario a sus dos pequeñas nietas, de forma que cuenten con una vida mejor por lo que su negocio es de mucha importancia, ya que es clave para la estabilidad de su familia. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de mercadería para la tienda, aumentado aquellos productos los cuales poseen más demanda, y de esta forma percibir más ganancias.
texts.en: Pastora V. C. is 75 years old and lives in Cojutepeque, located in the department of Cuscatlán where she lives with her minor granddaughters. She is a very courageous and hard working woman.  She has a store where she sells perishables and staples, which is a great support for herself and for her granddaughters who depend on this business. Pastora works hard to provide all the necessities to her two small granddaughters so that they have a better life. This is why her business is so important since it is the key to the stability of her family. She is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise for the store to increase those products which are in higher demand and thus earn more profits.

loans.use: Purchase perishables and staples to sell in her store.

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es: Lucia tiene 55 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos en su casa propia. DesD. hace 6 años venD. jugos en un puesto D. ventas, ubicado en un mercado pequeño cercano a su casa, en un inicio lo hacía D. manera ambulante. Ahora el negocio que posee le permite trabajar con toda tranquilidad y distribuir D. su tiempo para que pueda realizar diversas tareas que tiene dentro D. su hogar. En ocasiones su hija la ayuda en la atención y en la preparación D. jugos D. acuerdo a la preferencia y gusto del cliente.  Además D. jugos venD. mates D. hierbas calientes, que en su mayoría tiene propiedades medicinales que tiene mucha demanda. Para Lucia su negocio le es rentable, es por ello que desea renovar los artefactos que utiliza para la preparación D. jugos. Este es su crédito número 14 con MFP, esta muy contenta D.  saber que tiene un apoyo financiero por que sabe que le será  muy útil en el progreso D. su negocio. Por otro lado le agrada ser parte D. su banco comunal porque  todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra D. más mercadería en hierbas curativas, frutas y mejorar algunas herramientas que tiene en su  negocio como vasos nuevos y cubiertos.
texts.en: Lucia is 55 years old. She lives with her husband and 2 children in a house they own. For the last 6 years she has been selling juices in a kiosk located in a market close to her house; when she started out, she didn’t have a kiosk and had to walk around selling. Now her business allows her to work with tranquility and distribute her time according to the tasks she has at home. Sometimes her daughter helps tend the kiosk and makes the juice to the client’s liking. She doesn’t only sell juice, she also sells hot herbal infusions that have medicinal qualities and are in high demand. Lucia’s business is profitable and because of this, she would like to replace the equipment she uses to make juice. This is her 14th loan with MFP; she is very happy to have the financial support she needs, as she knows it will help her to grow her business. She is also very happy to be part of the communal bank because all of the members are responsible and supportive. With the loan she’s requesting, she’ll invest in more product like medicinal herbs and fruit, and buy new glasses and utensils.

loans.use: To buy fruits and medicinal herbs, as well as utensils and glasses.

loans.name: Enyonam Akuvi

texts.fr: Elle a 48 ans et mère de 4 enfants. Elle est mariée. Pour participer au menage, elle fait le commerce de pagne, vestes et chaussures. Elle exerce cette activité 10 ans déjà. Elle achète au grand marché de Lomé et revend à avepozo. Elle demande ce prêt pour acheter 30 pièces de pagnes.
texts.en: She is 48 years old and the mother of four. She is married. In order to contribute to the family budget, she sells traditional “pagnes” fabric, jackets and shoes. She has been in this business for 10 years already. She stocks up at the big market of Lomé and resells in Avepozo. She is requesting this loan in order to purchase 30 sets of “pagnes.”

loans.use: Purchasing traditional "pagnes" fabrics

loans.name: Flor Maria

texts.es:
Flor es socia del Bancomunal Musuq Wasi, tiene 38 años, es madre soltera con un hijo varon de 11 años.
Flor comenzó con la crianza de animales menores como son los cuyes, su casa está al costado de un grifo ahí decidió abrir una tienda y poco a poco comenzó a surtir su tienda, vende abarrotes en general, pollo, carne , verduras y aguas gaseosas.
El crédito que  solicita Flor lo invertirá para comprar mercaderías como: arroz, azúcar, fideos, leche, huevos, jabones, detergentes.
Desde que ingresó a Finca, su vida cambio, con los prestamos anteriores que ha recibido ha podido surtir su tienda. A Flor le gustan lasreuniones de su bancomunal porque puede ahorrar, en la capacitaciones aprendió a ser puntual responsable, a cuidar su salud y familia.  
El sueño de María Flor, es que su negocio crezca, y que su familia constituida por su padre e hijo siga unida con la bendición de Dios.
texts.en:
Flor is a member of the Musuq Wasi Communal Bank.  She is a 38 year old single mother, and she has an 11 year old son.  Flor started raising small animals like guinea pigs.  Her house is on the side of a gas station, and that is where she decided to open a store.  Little by little she began stocking her store.  She sells general groceries, chicken, meat, vegetables, and carbonated water.

The loan that Flor is requesting is to buy merchandise like rice, sugar, noodles, milk, eggs, soap, and detergent.

Ever since she became a member of Finca her life changed.  With the previous loans that she has received she has been able to stock her store.  Flor likes her communal bank meetings because she is able to save.  She also likes the trainings in which she learned to be punctual, responsible, and how to take care of her health and her family.

María Flor’s dream is that her business grows and that her family, comprised of her father and son, continues on together with God’s blessing.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, noodles, and milk

loans.name: Jimmy Edgar

texts.es: Cliente Vive en Parcona en la casa de sus Padres es soltero no tiene carga familiar tiene su transporte una Mototaxi quien lo maneja y le ayuda su hermano por que tiene negocio de carpinteria junto con su papa y hermanos su taller lo tiene en su mismo domicilio.Tiene endeudamiento a la fecha con Bco Crediscotia que fue para la Mototaxi le faltan dos cuotas para cancelar gracias a su trabajo de carpintero ha podido pagar la Moto y ahorrar.El es Buena Persona le ayuda a sus Padres  en los gastos de la Casa No tiene carga familiar.Tiene aspiraciones a tener su propio negocio necesita el credito para invertir en el negocio.
texts.en: Jimmy Edgar lives in Parcona in his parent's house.   He is single and has no dependents.  He has a mototaxi that he drives, and he also helps his brother with his carpentry business.  His brothers and his father have a carpentry workshop that is located in the home where he lives.  Jimmy currently has a loan from Banco Crediscotia that he used for his mototaxi.  He only has 2 more payments on that loan, thanks to his carpentry work, which allowed him to pay for the mototaxi and save.  He is a good person who helps his parents with the household expenses.  He aspires to have his own business, and he needs this loan to invest in his business.

loans.use: to invest in his business.

loans.name: Jessie Isabel

texts.en:
Jessie Isabel D. is from the village of Park Area, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 58 years old. Jessie Isabel is widowed and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Jessie Isabel owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, toothpaste, junk foods in the local community. Jessie Isabel has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jessie Isabel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jessie Isabel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Jessie Isabel is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like junk foods & canned goods. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Jessie Isabel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like junk foods & canned goods

location.town: North Park Area, Wao, Lanao de Sur

loans.name: Blanca Estela

texts.es: Blanca Estela S. D. I. D. 29 años D. edad, es una joven madre muy responsable y calificada por excelente persona por parte D. sus vecinos. Ella vive junto a dos hijos D. 8 y 5 años D. edad, y así mismo vive junto a su esposo quien posee una farmacia, en la cual Blanca le ayuda en sus tiempos libres. Blanca se dedica a la venta D. ropa para hombres mujeres y niños, la cual venD. D. forma ambulante por diferentes pueblos y cantones D. Ahuachapán, mismo departamento en el que resiD., ha pesar que este es un trabajo muy riesgoso ella lo realiza con la mejor voluntad D. salir adelante y darle una vida mejor a sus hijos. Blanca solicita un préstamo a Integral por medio del cual pueda comprar ropa por mayor, D. manera que pueda contar con más tallas, estilos y colores y así contar con más clientes.
texts.en:
Blanca Estela S. D. I. is a hard-working 29-year-old mother who is considered to be an excellent person by her neighbors. She lives with her children, ages 8 and 5, and her husband, who owns a pharmacy where Blanca helps out in her free time.

Blanca sells mens', womens' and childrens' clothing throughout the different towns and cantons in Ahuachapán Province.  Even though it is a risky business she is willing to do what is necessary in order to proviD. a better lifestyle for her children.  Blanca plans to use the loan she requested through Integral to buy clothing on a wholesale basis, and offer more variety in terms of size, style and color so she can increase her customer base.

loans.use: To buy clothing for retail sales

loans.name: Constante

texts.en:
Constante  M., 36, is married and the father of four children. He has been teaching for the past decade. 

Constante, who many describe as development-oriented and honest, has been teaching in quite a big number of schools in and around the district of Ntungamo. That partly explains why he gets a slightly higher remuneration than other teachers. He earns 800,000 shillings monthly from his teaching job. 

He also does some farming and cattle keeping for alternative sources of income. He says that with this loan, he is going to purchase land.

loans.use: To purchase land

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg is 54 years old and lives with her daughter, son-in-law and niece in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her son-in-law works as a bus driver for a company that transports people between Ulaanbaatar and the western provinces, and her daughter is currently unemployed. 

Oyunchimeg is a single mom who takes care of her children. She began a clothing trading business in 2010. She sells women's lingerie, hats and scarves in the winter at an outdoor stall where she pays 100,000 MNT a month for rent. Her daily income is about $57 and her monthly profit ranges between $244 and $325. She purchases her clothing once a month from China.

Oyumchimeg wants to rent another stall for her daughter where she can operate a clothing business and have her own income. Oyunchimeg says, "Now I am getting older, and I want my daughter to start a business and have a source of constant income." She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to rent one more stall and provide a job for her daughter.

loans.use: To rent one more stall

loans.name: Dennis

texts.en:
Dennis E. is from the village of Upper Carmen, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 30 years old. Dennis is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Dennis owns & operates a business buying and selling plastics & other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Dennis has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Dennis joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dennis has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional junk for sale & working capital.
